[Presidential elections](/wiki/Presidential_elections_in_Singapore) - [General elections](/wiki/General_elections_in_Singapore) Singapore portal - [Other countries](/wiki/Outline_of_political_science#Politics_by_region) - v - t - e Historically, women's involvement in Singapore's [political landscape](/wiki/Politics_of_Singapore) was limited. However, since 1984, there has been a steady rise in female participation, with more women contesting elections across both ruling and opposition parties, as well as taking on key political roles. ## History of women in Singaporean politics Singapore has practised [universal suffrage](/wiki/Universal_suffrage) from the outset of its democratic elections, unlike countries such as the United Kingdom and the United States. Early women representatives in the [Legislative Council](/wiki/Legislative_Council_of_Singapore) were mostly English-educated and middle-class. As women voters increased from 8 percent to 50 percent in 1955, Chinese-educated women leaders gained prominence. Some, including [Linda Chen Mock Hock](/wiki/Linda_Chen_Mock_Hock), were linked to [communism](/wiki/Communism) and were later suppressed under [Lim Yew Hock](/wiki/Lim_Yew_Hock)'s anti-communist administration. In 1959, four female [People's Action Party](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party) (PAP) candidates, including [Chan Choy Siong](/wiki/Chan_Choy_Siong) and Ho Puay Choo, entered the Assembly. Two women later defected to [Barisan Sosialis](/wiki/Barisan_Sosialis). After Chan's retirement in 1970, there was a 14-year absence of women in parliament. Female representation returned in (/wiki/1984_Singaporean_general_election) with [Dixie Tan](/wiki/Dixie_Tan), [Aline Wong](/wiki/Aline_Wong), and [Yu-Foo Yee Shoon](/wiki/Yu-Foo_Yee_Shoon) of the PAP. By 1988, four women were in parliament, but numbers dropped after 1991. From 2011, the number of women candidates and MPs steadily grew. The PAP Women's Wing was formed in 1989. In 1992, [Kanwaljit Soin](/wiki/Kanwaljit_Soin) became the first female [Nominated Member of Parliament](/wiki/Nominated_Member_of_Parliament), followed by others like [Eunice Olsen](/wiki/Eunice_Olsen), [Claire Chiang](/wiki/Claire_Chiang), Braema Mathiaparanam and [Yip Pin Xiu](/wiki/Yip_Pin_Xiu). Female politicians have since held higher office. [Grace Fu](/wiki/Grace_Fu) became the first female [Leader of the House](/wiki/Leader_of_the_House_(Singapore)) in 2015, while [Lim Hwee Hua](/wiki/Lim_Hwee_Hua) was Singapore’s first female Cabinet minister in 2009, though she lost her seat to the [Workers' Party](/wiki/Workers%27_Party_(Singapore)) (WP) in (/wiki/2011_Singapore_general_election). That same election saw the entry of WP's [Sylvia Lim](/wiki/Sylvia_Lim) as the first elected female opposition MP, and [Lina Loh](/wiki/Lina_Loh) as an NCMP. In 2013, [Halimah Yacob](/wiki/Halimah_Yacob) became the first female [Speaker](/wiki/Speaker_of_the_Parliament_of_Singapore) and later, in 2017, the first female [President](/wiki/President_of_Singapore). In 2020, [Josephine Teo](/wiki/Josephine_Teo) led a PAP team as anchor minister, while WP gained ground with [He Ting Ru](/wiki/He_Ting_Ru) and [Raeesah Khan](/wiki/Raeesah_Khan), the latter being the youngest and first minority opposition MP. [Hazel Poa](/wiki/Hazel_Poa) of the [Progress Singapore Party](/wiki/Progress_Singapore_Party) became the third female NCMP, though she later lost her seat. In 2025, WP retained its female MPs He and Lim, and added [Eileen Chong](/wiki/Eileen_Chong_(politician)) as the fourth female NCMP. The table below shows the comparison and number of female candidates who contested over the years since the first post-independence election in 1968, and eventually elected in office: YearNumber of female candidatesRepresentationRemarksPAPOppositionTotalSeatsPercentage(/wiki/2025_Singaporean_general_election)29/322/2131/5331/9731.96%Excluding one NCMP.(/wiki/2020_Singaporean_general_election)24/253/1527/4027/9329.03%Excluding one NCMP.(/wiki/2015_Singaporean_general_election)20/201/1521/3521/8923.59%(/wiki/2011_Singaporean_general_election)18/201/1519/3519/8721.84%Excluding one NCMP, and one MP-elect in a by-election.(/wiki/2006_Singaporean_general_election)18/180/418/2218/8421.42%Excluding one NCMP.(/wiki/2001_Singaporean_general_election)10/100/110/1110/8411.90%(/wiki/1997_Singaporean_general_election)4/40/04/44/834.82%(/wiki/1991_Singaporean_general_election)2/30/22/52/812.47%(/wiki/1988_Singaporean_general_election)4/40/54/94/814.94%(/wiki/1984_Singaporean_general_election)3/30/33/63/793.80%(/wiki/1980_Singaporean_general_election)0/00/20/20/750.00%(/wiki/1976_Singaporean_general_election)0/00/10/10/690.00%Amnah binte Kuong Hussein of the [Singapore Malay National Organisation](/wiki/Singapore_Malay_National_Organisation) (PKMS) contested in the [Geylang Serai Constituency](/wiki/Geylang_Serai_Constituency).(/wiki/1972_Singaporean_general_election)0/00/10/10/650.00%Normah binte Yahya of the WP contested in the [Changi Constituency](/wiki/Changi_Constituency).(/wiki/1968_Singaporean_general_election)1/10/00/00/580.00%[Chan Choy Siong](/wiki/Chan_Choy_Siong) of the PAP contested in the [Delta Constituency](/wiki/Delta_Constituency) and was re-elected unopposed. She had been serving in that constituency since (/wiki/1959_Singaporean_general_election). ## Current women parliamentarians Since the 1990s, the number of women participating in politics has progressively increased, and it hit double digits towards the 3rd millennium and the representation for female MPs increase per every election. There are currently 31 elected women parliamentarians out of a total of 97 elected members. The list of women parliamentarians are listed in alphabetical order by surnames. ### Distribution LevelNumberNamesCabinet Ministers (including second ministers and Minister-in-charge)3[Grace
